I wrote a tutorial on setting up a #RaspberryPi to produce an interactive programming environment and to fetch your email from the command line.

You'll quickly be able to create apps for desktop, mobile or the web.

We'll create a script that will sync with your gmail inbox (or any other service that supports IMAP forwarding) and automatically check for new messages every 5 minutes, without ever leaving the terminal!

"What's a terminal? Are you threatening me?"

Many modern computer users may not have ever seen a terminal/console/command prompt before, because our Windows/Mac/Linux graphical desktop systems now do everything for us so we can just point and click on stuff and spill coffee on ourselves. But the way to gain backstage access to the show is still through interacting with text files, and that's not gonna change anytime soon - words are what humans use to communicate with machines as well as each other. In this blog series we will explore how to get started. Rock on!

The inspiration for this blog series is to demonstrate how the software community is making great advances in bridging the gap between theory and practice. In this lesson we will explore how automata, the most basic models introduced in computer science textbooks can be used to solve real problems.

I realized too that I needed to make an easy guide to learn programming from the ground up:
http://crjunkie.blogspot.com/2017/11/programming-beginners-guide.html
It covers the very basics of setting up your software development environment.

You're also welcome to follow this and other nerdy posts on my nerd page, @[143282876171253:274:Internet of Non-Things].

http://crjunkie.blogspot.com/2017/11/theory-of-computation-finite-state.html
http://crjunkie.blogspot.com/2017/11/my-interview-for-apple.html

In order to work for Apple, my first test is to rescue Santa's sleigh which was stolen by the Easter bunny. I'm dropped off in the middle of a city with an impossibly long list of directions and to reach my goal I have to write a program that will calculate the "Manhattan distance", the shortest path along a grid,  which is equal to the sum of the absolute differences of the Cartesian coordinates. That's really just a fancy way of asking, "How far is it in each direction?"

So I made that function and parsed the directions into a sequence of steps and turns, and then appropriately incremented or decremented my coordinates according to the direction of travel, determined by dividing the value of the number of turns by 4 and taking the remainder. And it works!

Source code:
https://github.com/porkostomus/advent-of-code-2016
So far so good, 2 more problems to go!

I've been corresponding with a little computer company in California called Apple Inc. They make sorta classy-looking plastic shit, and are looking to hire a full-time web developer. A recruiter contacted me via LinkedIn, so I sent my resume and he offered me $110k/yr salary. He just sent me some kind of coding screening test to take before we schedule an interview. I might wanna go see what that's all about.

I am beginning the development of the @[251540665307856:274:MECCA Music Platform] (Music Education, Composition, Creation Application), which will leverage the new Overtone music framework and SuperCollider audio engine, some really awesome technologies that, when incorporated as part of a new digital audio suite will make every aspect of learning and producing music more intuitive and expressive.

The idea is to focus on acoustic modeling, providing comprehensive synth editors that allow you to dynamically construct virtual instruments using simple oscillators and effect processors. Instead of relying on prerecorded samples, you learn to produce all of the music yourself from the pure sonic building blocks by tuning the specific variables.

I'm doing this because the world needs more people making music. Like everyone! I agree strongly with Daniel Levitin who explains in his book This Is Your Brain On Music that a much unfortunate and unique phenomenon has happened in our culture where we have taken on the perception that you have to be talented to do art. Compared to other activities, it is pretty absurd that we should demand such a high level of aptitude just to be considered acceptable. If you cannot prepare a meal like a master chef, do you not cook dinner? If you cannot play a sport like the pros, should you not be able to enjoy a game with your friends?

With all the impressive advances in software sequencers and virtual instruments, I believe we can be doing a whole lot more to put powerful music creation tools into the hands of people of every skill level. That's what this platform is all about!

Want to know more? Feel free to visit the page and get involved!
http://overtone.github.io/
http://supercollider.github.io/

data.post:
That's a very fine idea! Maybe I'll get a new ukulele, bedazzle it and do a tour as @[606539822826740:274:GrungeBob PukeyPants]! More travel-friendly, tucks away securely inside a jacket or sleeping bag, and works great for slide: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kef1vrMZMK4

People on the street are starting to think that I'm Weird Al.
So I should do a song that's a parody of a Weird Al parody. I wonder how that would work? I could take snippets of his most famous ones (Amish Paradise, etc.) and sing about how my entire career is based off of singing other musicians' songs but with stupid words. We shall see!
Thinking of heading North today on foot to Washington.

New instrument!

I got a little pink disney princess keyboard for $3 at Goodwill.
Works great but needs to be louder, so I got a portable speaker for $5 and gutted it, and spliced the keyboard's original speaker wires to the line in of the new one, causing it to overdrive and sound like it's gonna explode! 

It works like a charm but now I need a soldering iron to finish the wiring and mount the speakers, circuit boards and battery holder all inside it. Then I want to rig it up with pedals so I can play bass with my feet.

Finally, all my instruments and electronics will be fitted with explosives and detonators, set to self-distruct and incapacitate user in case of unauthorized removal.

They might as well have pissed all over me while I was sleeping.

That's how dirty it feels. 

My guitar was stolen last night. That sucks, but you didn't even know I had a guitar because I hadn't even gotten around to telling you yet. It's a shame to have to find out like this, going along with this post's rather crude nature, when the emotional depth and full impact of the situation can only be expressed in the full context of a couple other major life events - the loss of the use of my fretting hand, and my grandma's recent passing. Recent as in the other day. Yes, what a bother to find out like this.

Before going to sleep, I wisely thought to secure my new guitar by tying it to myself. I wasn't concerned about people with malicious tendencies lurking about, this was just an extra precaution to prevent a passerby from thinking "oh that's a nice looking guitar, I think I'll grab that". They didn't bother untying the cable though - instead they cut it off of me with wire cutters. Yuck.... feels so much like piss all over my face.

I had finally saved up enough to get a decent acoustic guitar. I hadn't really played guitar in a couple years, because it was too frustrating trying to learn it lefty. But I can still play keyboards just fine, so it was easier to just go with that. But ever since my harmonium was stolen over 6 months ago, I'd been without any instruments. An essential part of my self expression and livelihood missing, I found it easier to occupy myself with other things to fill the creative void, like computer programming, and that turned out to be one of the most exciting developments in my life. But just last week, I decided it was time to start making music again... I wanted to get a GUITAR. To face the one thing that I still feel like I lost - since my accident 2 years ago I have been dodging the tragic reality that I will never play guitar again, at least anything like how I used to. I wanted to force myself to face it, and actually learn to play it left-handed no matter how difficult.

It didn't quite work out that way - because after a few days, I realized I can totally play slide guitar! With a couple days' practice, I found myself able to play anything I wanted to, as well as I ever could! It was such a breakthrough... 

Music was suddenly back in my life. And then I found out that my grandma had passed away, who was the greatest musical influence in my family. The timing was so right I wanted to ask the cosmos if they were fucking with me.

I spent all day yesterday setting up the guitar for slide. I fashioned my own custom piece to raise the string action out of the plastic outside of a magic marker using nothing but a lighter and a pack of emery boards. I was so proud of myself, it turned out perfectly and sounded so amazing! And my playing was so solid I was suddenly experiencing the healing of my deepest emotional wounds.

But now it's gone... some asshole crouched over me with wire cutters and removed it from my person, and metaphorically peed all over me. 

There will be more guitars though. 

I love my grandma.

RIP Ruth Towers

I hitchhiked 300 miles to go to the job fair and was turned away because I didn't have the $30 entrance fee, which I found no mention of anywhere beforehand.

Tried to go to the job fair at PyCon. Was turned away because I didn't have the $30 entrance fee.

Saw a guy reading a MySQL handbook this morning at the Portland Rescue Mission. SQL is the standard for database management, and currently the most demanded programming language in the tech industry. We shared a brief moment of warmth and free coffee together, as I read my book on Clojure, the language for which the latest Stack Overflow developer survey reports the highest earned wage worldwide.

Walked by the Apple store on my way to the university. Resisted the urge to open the door and yell, "congratulations, you are selling JUNK!" At least the heroin dealers won't try to sugar-coat the reality that their product will work great for a short time but tomorrow you're going to be sick and need to buy another.

Next block over - Microsoft store, see above.

The world is not ready for where we are going. In our efforts to produce goods and services, we are preventing access to them by the very people who could benefit from them the most. The motivation is not actually to improve the world - only to profit from it.

I can see what needs to change. And I'm not gonna be quiet about it.

This is gonna sound strange, but I've often felt that the songs that a musician chooses to cover can potentially reveal an even deeper aspect of their creative artistry than their originals. With all the songs in the world... why on earth did I choose those to learn and record? In a slightly egotistical way, it's like the biggest compliment to another artist, that I would for whatever reason take the time and life-force energy to sit down and learn to imitate someone else's creation. An incredibly powerful statement that goes unrecognized.

I didn't realize I had recorded so many Chris Cornell songs... Not only that, but it is very significant that when I first got a ukulele and started this YouTube channel, they were the first songs that I decided to learn.

This is quite the development to attempt to process... so to begin by gathering and reviewing the songs he recorded that I was inspired to cover.

I wasn't actually a big Soundgarden fan, until I started seriously studying vocal technique. It was then that I discovered that Chris was considered by many to be the greatest voice in rock since Robert Plant. Interestingly, they both sang the same range of notes, but while Plant's voice type is a tenor as you'd expect, Cornell was a baritone. That's part of the magic that was his voice - he had the richness of a baritone but could sing insanely high. This cover was requested by @[1633194093:2048:Adrienne Seese]. I didn't feel like learning the song, so I skipped that part...

"Someone tried to tell me something...
Don't let the world bring you down".

My favorite Soundgarden song, complete with all my mistakes. Now why would I bother to actually learn the song first? If I had, I probably never would have recorded it!

Premature perfectionism is the root of all evil. Just make stuff. No matter how bad it sucks.

Kurt Cobain's death was one of the most significant events of my adolescence, and I still have trouble dealing with how exactly to form my perspective and rationalize living in a world that he chose to leave. Now I have to ask the same question again... What in the world, I must ask, could possibly be so bad? 

Life is full of pain, but we are completely blinded to the gifts the future holds for us.

Please, I beg of all people of earth... 

Don't ever let that go!

This was one of the first songs I ever learned on ukulele. This is from his solo album that he did with Timbaland - the founding grunge vocalist shocked the rock community by boldly producing an album that was all electronic. I'm working on a new version to post as a tribute.

This campaign was started to build a workshop in which to manufacture the computers I am designing. In the first week $105 was raised of the $500 goal, and has kinda stalled out....however, a new opportunity has come about that could place the goal much, much closer:

As of now, I have gained access to a state of the art maker space of my dreams, right here in Portland. I can use it for up to 35 hours a week, for free! There are 3D printers galore, CNC machines, laser cutters....everything I could possibly need!

Wow! Since the workshop is already available to me, that means all I need to purchase are materials. So lets figure out where we stand and recalculate the budget:

The e-ink display and circuit boards have arrived. The rest of the components for the display driver still need to be purchased. We no longer need the 3D printer, soldering station or any tools. Everything else that is needed is batteries and paint.

That puts me about $50 away!
That's a lot less than $400...

data.post: Leave a comment if you are someone who makes things. Tag your Facebook Page. I want to get all the creative people I know connected in a new way!

I'm pleased to be contributing to Street Roots, Portland's weekly newspaper that empowers people from all walks of life to expand community awareness. During my time at The Challenger Street Newspaper in Austin, I saw the power of a publication produced authentically by the community to offer the voice of the streets, a scene that I believe to be a sign of a healthy, vibrant culture. 

What does a healthy community look like? 
PEOPLE HANGING OUT, OUTSIDE!

Whoa... all those homeless people... GROSS! What can we do about them? Where can we shuffle them off too?

Imagine that maybe, people sometimes congregate outdoors and socialize, do various business and participate in the advancement of humanity.

Fear and disgust of normal human behavior come from lack of knowledge, and this is where a street paper strikes so effectively. In order to move forward, we need to realize that we are a SUPERORGANISM, that our cooperative actions have the power to multiply individual efforts into long-term social change. To do this we need to expand the "I".

Who am I? My basic model of self-awareness tells me that I am most likely a sack of meat that can make decisions, even advanced long-term goal-oriented  ones. But the bigger truth that we are on the path towards internalizing is that we are all expressions of humanity on planet Earth, transforming our surroundings through our creative potential.

Take a moment to delight in getting to know someone "different" who you don't understand - and try to realize that they are YOU.

This is such a simple concept, yet it begins to smell of spiritual mumbo jumbo, social justice warriorism, or neo-Jungian Quantum flap-doodle, but I'm just trying to loosen our social bubbles and release the echos from the chambers that divide us from other groups whom we perceive as different and thus whatever degree of objectionable our subconscious responds with.

Looking at all of human history we have come so far... but psychological evolution lags behind by something like 10,000 years if I remember correctly. In other words, our minds are still adapted to the world as it was 10,000 years ago.

That means that people living in houses could be considered a FAD. We have completely transformed the world to suit a new way of life that we don't understand at all...

I'm in Portland on a job-search mission, and I'm back at my old college where I was doing the music program. Have to wait 'till Monday to see my professors again, but I've got a great vision about something I could do here! 

It's called: "Adieu, Sweet Barbary Allen", an animated folk/rock opera based on the classic Scottish/Irish love ballad.

I came up with the idea last year, perplexed by my own obsession with this amazing song... like the Romeo and Juliet story, but harder hitting in some ways that I'm still exploring.  I realized that it would be perfect for an opera, with the verses of the song serving as a recurring motif connecting a series of original musical compositions that advance the plot and take us through some interesting twists.

That sounds rather ambitious... but here's the kicker: I've got all the songs written already! 9 of them, and half are already recorded!

It's true... as I went through my own discography I was shocked to only learn now that ALMOST EVERY SONG I'VE WRITTEN IS (or could be interpreted as) A LOVE TRAGEDY! I went through them last night and laid out a storyboard for a new album and animated film to produce HERE, at the college as a collaborative project. It begs to be part of the curriculum, because it grew directly from its heart: The History of American Folk.

I wasn't even particularly excited about the course because I'm not that into Folk music so naturally it sounded kinda boring. But I was in for a huge surprise. The music professor gave us a brilliant tour of the genesis of American music showcasing how the songs evolved through the Folk *process*, and this tune as sung by Jean Ritchie was so gorgeous I practically melted into my seat: https://youtu.be/9l3VePGR-QA
 At the time, I was intensely learning some new electronic music production software, so I got the crazy idea to put "The Blues" back into dance music by making Folk-Dubstep! 

This is what came about, made with Logic Pro 9 and MASSIVE. I lifted the vocals straight from the a cappela video below and simply formed a modern musical setting around them: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yQzVAFyQbYk

The track was a huge success, and emerges as a shining representation of the "Folk Process" still at work, perpetuated by our modern interpretations of the classics. I can see this project as a way to unify the whole curriculum. It's history, theory, performance, drama and multimedia. The animation department is even right in the music wing!

It's wonderful to be back. I could definitely do some stuff here.

external_context.name: LinuxFest Northwest

data.post: Tomorrow, I'm gonna hitchhike to a computer nerd-fest. Gotta get 563 miles in 2 days.

https://www.linuxfestnorthwest.org/2017
Anyone wanna take me here this weekend? It's free, and I'm sure to find some great opportunities.
Where can I watch the new Bill Nye show besides Netflix?

Money is not the only way to contribute to this startup effort: Last week I made a post that I'm looking for old laptops in any condition. The reason is: I want to restore them however necessary so they can be used by people who cannot afford their own computers.

I intend to file for nonprofit status and follow in the footsteps of charities like Raspberry Pi Foundation, who provide truly affordable technology to computer science, and the On It Foundation, who offer free computers and training to students and families.

But there's no reason to wait for the paperwork to begin doing this. Send me your outdated/broken stuff, and I'll make it into a device that someone will use to get their work done and learn new skills.

If the screen is broken, I'll replace it!
If the insides are completely fried, I'll put in new guts!
If the components are fine but the housing is smashed, I'll make a new case for it!
And then... you could even have it back if you want.

It cuts down on waste, and fights against planned obsolescence.

Vocalists I pretend to sound like (one is fake):

1. James Brown
2. Britney Spears
3. Serj Tankian
4. Howlin' Wolf
5. Elvis
6. Angela Gossow
7. Tom Waits
8. Kurt Cobain
9. Little Richard
10. Aretha Franklin

In interest of absolute transparency with this project and as a demonstration of my gratitude and commitment to all current and potential donors, I will be documenting all purchases and keeping you updated along the way. It has only been 2 days and the goal is still distant, but this gofundme campaign has already been a success! Here's a full breakdown of where we stand, and how I plan to use the funds this week:

The 3D printer will probably have to wait. The model I am looking at is the Monoprice Select Mini. It is $214.50 on Amazon and has great reviews, which I think is incredible! I listed it as part of the proposal because it will be the ideal production method for the enclosures, but the logical order of design will be to put that on the back burner for now and focus on the electronics first, since a laptop case can be improvised should the goal fail to be met. After all, better to have a working prototype with no case, than a nice looking case that doesn't do anything!

Components already on hand: Raspberry Pi 3, USB keyboard and mouse. In order to create a working unit, we need to order a screen and the parts to build the driver board.

Good news: The ereader display is only $18.90 on ebay! This will be the first thing to get. Then we have the most challenging part - the circuit board and components, and the tools to solder everything. It uses surface mount components which are typically installed by robots, but this can reasonably be done by hand so that's how we roll. Let's break it down:

Circuit board must be ordered in a minimum quantity of 3, which is $30.15. Components will cost around $25. Then I just need to figure out the most practical and economical way to connect them to the board. The most common way to do this is with solder paste and a reflow oven, or a heat gun. But I'm gonna try it with a regular iron by simply globbing it on and removing the excess with copper wicking. It will require lots of patience, a steady hand and possibly magnification.

So the bottom line is, we're pretty much in business! I can order this stuff this week, and we'll see how the campaign continues to unfold! Thanks everyone!

Off to a great start! I can already order some parts and start building one. In the mean time I can talk about 2 models I came up with - the Jack Kerouac, and the Kerouac Lite:

The Jack Kerouac model is an actual manual typewriter with the guts removed and an e-reader screen built into it! The Kerouac Lite is inspired by the same design but will be 3D-printed so way less heavy.

Additional features:  They will have a touchpad that slides out from underneath the keyboard. What for? So you can use it to surf the web! It will come pre-installed with Wikipedia so you can do research even without WiFi.
This is phase 1 - everything I'll need to set up a workshop, build a prototype and develop a product line.

I'm creating a portable computer with an e-ink screen, designed for writers, hackers, and anyone who works with text for long periods of time. I'll be putting together a crowdfunding campaign, but first I'd like to find a couple of "casual" supporters, so I can get some tools and supplies to build a prototype as a proof of concept.

There is currently no affordable device that offers this functionality which addresses two important issues - battery life, and eye strain. Backlit displays are harsh on the eyes and limit productivity, drain your batteries, and are useless in sunlight.

My original idea was to hack a Nook or a Kindle (which run Android) to use it as a remote desktop, but this requires WiFi - a big drawback. Imagine a device that would be completely useless without being connected to a network - unacceptable as a marketable solution. The better option is to reverse-engineer a driver for an e-ink display, and I have found a way to do it for about $50. That's $25 for the screen, and $25 for the parts to build the driver. 

What do you guys think? I really wanna make this thing! Once I get the electronics working, I can get to the fun part of designing a beautiful case and putting it all together. It will basically look like a netbook, a small clamshell-type hinged laptop with a physical keyboard suitable for serious typing. And of course, it will come in pretty colors!
I want your old laptops

"Makers are seeking an alternative to being regarded as consumers, rejecting the idea that you are defined by what you buy. Instead, makers have a sense of what they can do and what they can learn to do. Like artists, they are motivated by internal goals, not extrinsic rewards. They are inspired by the work of others. Most importantly, they do not wait until the future to create and make. They feel an urgency to do something nowâ or lose the opportunity to do it at all."ï¿½

So... who has seen this thing made by @[628821723950814:274:REMARKABLE]? I know @[1047678684:2048:Kylie K Wall] has. Yes it's the most awesome thing ever made and I absolutely hate it because no one will buy me one and I'll never be able to afford $400 for a piece of pseudo-paper with a magic techno-pen.

So I started thinking... I bet I could make something kinda like that, not nearly as crazystupidamazingawesomely cool, but still "pretty cool", for like, less than half the price. I do want this thing so bad... but for the time being, I'm gonna have to make one myself. Sorta.

But when I started brainstorming on it... I realized that my po-boy version was turning out to be something rather different. Something actually pretty cool in its own way... and then....

A BREAKTHROUGH!!!!

Seriously... I think you guys are all gonna shit when you see this. 

https://remarkable.imgix.net/rasters/remarkable-read.jpg?q=50&w=417.08&dpr=1.2
I'm in the middle of the premier facebook-reveal of the laptop that I've been designing since September of 2012. But first... I wanna talk about touchscreens. How do you guys feel about touchscreens?

I found a super-geeky meetup group of local hackers/makers so I'm gonna go and deliver them an incredible hardware pitch for a new laptop I've been working on. I'm really excited and hopeful for an opportunity to gather some much needed interest (maybe even venture-capital? Now let's not get THAT hopeful...).

Keeping with my custom of casting all my half-baked ideas to YOU first, my dear Facebookers, I shall now present my vision: 

I feel that we are now at a technological crossroads of a magnitude that has not happened since 1976, when the very first home computers were put together in the garages of Silicon Valley, and I'm imagining this meetup group to be the 2017 version of the Homebrew Computer Club, where Steve Wozniak showed up with his work of pure genius made from "liberated" computer parts. When his friend Steve Jobs saw this thing, it would eventually be marketed as the original Apple Computer.

Yes, Apple totally sucks now, but I've got to find inspiration in their exemplary product development and marketing strategies. In particular, the unique ability to detect a potential widespread application of the emerging innovation and boldly package it as functional tech-art. I've been working on this project for 5 years now, and I think the time is right for it to be released. But I'm gonna need some help... which I hope to recruit tonight - I need to find my Steve Jobs!

So here's the thing: I'll just spill it all right here and anyone is welcome to steal my idea and make millions off it - then I'll just save my money for the next 10 years till one day I'll have the $200 to be able to buy it from you. 

If it existed, I would stand on the corner and panhandle for it (and I won't even do that for food). But nobody has made this thing, I've looked everywhere, and there are some really cool things deep in the super-nerd-circles, but not even close to what I'm building. And those that are a little bit sorta-close... are all SOLD OUT and unavailable because they can't keep up with the demand!!!

I'm talking about a new kind of computer. Check it out -

Those of you who grew up in the '80s and '90s remember it all. The fullfillment of Bill Gates' dream of a personal computer on every desk in every home. Then in the next 2 decades we sat back and watched that slowly but surely turn into every pocket and every purse. And if you walk into a coffee shop or university, what do you see? Glowing Apples in front of every face. And these new laptops are so freakishly light and thin you could practically use it as a frisbee and float it right over to the Starbucks on the other side of the street. But, damn... are they expensive!

I bought my Macbook Pro in 2013, because I got so fed up with my $700 laptop that I had been using for 10 years, and I had just gone back to school so for the first time had actual shit to get done, that I decided to blow my funding for the entire semester on a new computer, and eat nothing but McDonald's and Ramen noodles for the next 3 months. Just so that for ONCE... I would actually have something that WORKS.

Was it worth it? I thought so. I got Logic Pro and Ableton Live and produced an entire album just in the first month. I learned to do 3D modeling using the same software that South Park uses (ironically, to emulate the classic style of cardboard-cutout animation!). I could have 27 browser tabs open while editing images and video, or run 12 instances of MASSIVE synths making the most disgusting bass noises - but the computer would never, ever even gag on all that sickness. That computer changed my life....

But not as much as this one.

Oops... see, I got so caught up in this here introduction, I seem to have run out of caffeine! I'm gonna post this now and make some coffee. If you've read this far, drop me a comment if you want all the details...

data.post:
Some cool new stuff! Settled on a name for my set of music production tools, decided to go with an acronym: MECCA, the Music Education, Composition and Creation Application. Next step after naming a project is a Facebook page, so here's that.

Other stuff: Seeking alternatives to gmail, I decided to try mail.com. It seems great, I registered empowernutrition@mail.com as well as iont@mail.com for Internet of Non-Things (my web development company that Facebook doesn't let me tag for some stupid reason). It seems that mail.com might limit your number of accounts because the next one failed, so I thought I'd try Zoho Mail (https://www.zoho.com/mail/). Was easy enough, so I got meccaplatform@zoho.com.

For website deployment, I just started using http://surge.sh/ and it's awesome! It allows you to publish a site to the web in seconds, with the address http://whateveryouwant.surge.sh directly from your command line. I'm gonna start using this all the time.

Attention all musicians, non-musicians, composers, programmers, teachers, and producers:

I urgently request your feedback and collaboration! I've been designing a set of software tools that I think have the power to redefine the whole musical landscape, by providing a unified platform for education, composition, production and performance. 

It's vital that I gather enough creative support to make this happen - not for me, or the students or the teachers, composers, singers dancers djs or whomever...  the very state of human creativity is in our hands! I know what we've been missing, and how we can work together to achieve the next wave of sonic expression! Let's have a discussion...
Fear not the singularity of intelligent Things... stick to the Non-Things.

Here's my personal take on Elon Musk's goal of integrating technology directly into our brains: It has a tremendous potential that is not at all related to his actual motivation... Yes! Augmenting our innate cognitive ability by directly implanting computerized processing into our neurons to form a new kind of composite intelligence sounds great! Robotic brain-lice? Yes please! Yes! Imagine what we could do with electronics mounted in our skulls! The possibilities are endless... but we aren't gonna become cyborgs any time soon. I do have another idea though, that we VERY WELL COULD DEVELOP through this proposed technoganic hybridization:

ELECTRONIC STIMULATION OF NEURAL RECEPTORS. This could completely eliminate the need for psychoactive drugs!

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_brain_stimulation

They already do this in rodent studies, to study the long-term effects of cocaine for example. They don't actually use cocaine! They implant electrodes to stimulate the dopamine receptors, mimicking the effects of the drug. It's still far off from being implemented in humans, but it's definitely possible, and nobody seems to be at all considering the scale of the medical benefits that could be enabled by gaining control of our neurotransmitters without the use of chemicals.

For sure, don't tell your drug dealer. He'll be out of a job, as will the cartels and the pharmaceutical companies. Think about it! I can imagine in the foreseeable future an individual legitamately suffering from Attention Deficit Disorder or Parkinson's Disease being interfaced with a computerized dopamine regulation mechanism instead of given chemical stimulants like Adderall or Ritalin. Another patient with symtoms of schizophrenia would get the opposite - inhibition of the same neurotransmitters. We will be literally downloading all of our medications directly into our brains to address a huge variety of psychological issues. Software designers could even develop "recreational drug apps" that would modify our brain chemistry in creative ways to acheive certain mental states.

Here it is @[100000443911899:2048:Andy Hitchcock], I knew it was coming! A review of Elon Musk's new "venture" from Steven Novella, one of the only science communicators I completely trust.

Here's a nice quote from him on the @[16599501604:274:The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe] podcast:
"The whole science fiction behind Skynet becoming self-aware, it's bullshit. That's the 1950s naive sense that if a computer just becomes smart enough and fast enough and powerful enough it will 'wake up', but that's not going to happen."

My reflections on this amazing analysis made by a data scientist at @[166471303706:274:OkCupid] are being developed into a central focal point of my book @[1878504605760804:274:Ambient Narcissism], which deals with the intersection of psychology and sociology with the development of information technology, exploring how our self-awareness, personality expression, and pursuit of interpersonal relationships form a complex feedback system that has been transformed by the explosive new era of digital communication into a radical new mechanism of human growth.

I plan on releasing the book next year, in recognition and  celebration of the past 10 years since the widespread adoption of electronic social media. Go ahead and like the page for the latest stuff!

https://theblog.okcupid.com/the-8-personalities-youll-meet-when-dating-in-the-u-s-9d87a5a40274

We might have had a feeling that places like the NW and Colorado are more "outdoorsy, non-judgmental, non-religious, politically liberal and even more drug-friendly" when compared to other regions in the US, but now it's SCIENCE.

Yes, bleeding-edge socio-geographical data science from none other than... a dating website. But a very nerdy one that particularly excels with personality statistics... providing an unprecedented level of insight into what we individually consider to be life's most important issues. It's a shame that people in general tend to be quite shallow and much of the online relationship discovery marketplace shifted to Tinder and the rest of the "2nd generation" dating apps which bring the process of meeting people back closer to the traditional experience - one based on superficial, physical attraction. This article at https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/08/opinion/sunday/in-defense-of-tinder.html?_r=0 gives a well reasoned explanation in support of the established social paradigm, but I think we are failing to appreciate the tremendous advancement made possible through this expanded access to each other's (hopefully) truthful outlook. I think it represents a major evolution in the way we form relationships that has been made possible by technological innovation enabling enhanced communication.

It is clear to anyone familiar with OKCupid that their best feature is the match questions. When I realized how powerful they are at sorting personality traits, I spent an incredible amount of time fine-tuning my answers, and in the process made some of the most meaningful lifelong friendships, and also learned a whole lot about MYSELF!  By carefully comparing your answers (which are grouped into lifestyle categories AND ranked by subjective importance), you could often form a freakishly comprehensive prediction of how the two of you get along. Of course there's still the question of relationship chemistry that is only revealed when you meet in person, but the BIG ISSUES, like how compatible you are intellectually, politically, religiously, sexually, etc. are already on the table. Many of us (myself included) discovered through our experience that if you had a high match score with someone, it was almost guaranteed that you had found (at least) a potential BFF.

This geographical personality analysis of over 600 million responses "counted how often members in 945 Census-defined Metropolitan Statistical Areas (MSAs) gave a particular answer . . . [then] used a statistical method called factor analysis to find patterns based on which responses tend to co-occur in different cities."

"To determine the traits that the responses may signify, we looked at the answers with the largest positive (or negative) point values, and figured out what word or concept best described the pattern we saw. This partâs a bit subjective, but most will find that the overlap between answers of particular questions certainly makes some clear suggestions about the respondentâs personality. The factor analysis found that U.S. cities differ along 13 primary personality scales."

This was like the "Grunge" movement of classical music. Beethoven was Metal, and Chopin was... well, something else. Whatever, Debussy is awesome. Listen to it.

The reason I said "grunge" is what he did by pushing the boundaries of harmonic convention. So did Bach, so did Beethoven... Chopin for sure... but Debussy pushed it somewhere else. Particularly in this Book II we have in this here playlist...These compositions are just downright weird... but most people I think would still call it "beautiful music",

Shoenberg pushed the limits of tonality further... but when I put that on, people say, "Ow, that hurts my ears!"

Funny thing is, I was just looking for this particular playlist the other day, but got sidetracked before I could search back through 4 years of Facebook posts. Then today it pops up as a memory. Apparently I wanted to listen to Debussy exactly at this time 4 years ago....

GET RID OF YOUR ADDERALL, AND YOUR SUGAR.

media.description:
Image credits

Background:
NGC 2170: Still Life with Reflecting Dust
Image Credit & Copyright: Adam Block, Mt. Lemmon SkyCenter, U. Arizona

Explanation: In this beautiful celestial still life composed with a cosmic brush, dusty nebula NGC 2170 shines at the upper left. Reflecting the light of nearby hot stars, NGC 2170 is joined by other bluish reflection nebulae, a compact red emission region, and streamers of obscuring dust against a backdrop of stars. Like the common household items still life painters often choose for their subjects, the clouds of gas, dust, and hot stars pictured here are also commonly found in this setting - a massive, star-forming molecular cloud in the constellation of the Unicorn (Monoceros). The giant molecular cloud, Mon R2, is impressively close, estimated to be only 2,400 light-years or so away. At that distance, this canvas would be about 15 light-years across.

data.post: I've been fighting with Wikipedia administrators all week. For several years I've been making my own pages as study guides (in my user space, not in the main encyclopedia) because I really like the wiki format. It's super handy to have a collection of links you find most relevant to a topic all together. But then one day they deleted all my stuff, and when I freaked out and demanded a reason they were like "well you've been mucking about for like 7 years only fixing typos and storing your notes, how about actually submitting an article?" So now they are holding all my notes ransom until I prove that I'm actually interested in building the encyclopedia. I got to pick one of the hostages (topics) to be released so I can make it into an article. So now I have to write about the history of computer programming language paradigms. Once I submit it to Wikipedia for review, they will undelete the rest of my stuff!

There was a story in the news this week citing a popular psychologist who stated that ADHD was a hoax. My favorite neurologist,  dr. Steven novella responded that it is absolutely not true, it is in fact a very real disorder.

this was exactly the topic of my final paper for psychology Last Summer. I began the paper with the hypothesis that it was a hoax, but during the course of my research proved myself wrong. I was so happy to hear my conclusion confirmed by someone I respect so highly, I decided to dig up my paper and post it here in its entirety:

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder and the Development of Executive Function

Robert J. Towers
Austin Community College
Intro to Psychology - Summer 2016
Instructor: Nancy Bellows
407B W 35th St, Austin TX 78705

Abstract:

For research of a psychological
disorder, attention deficit
hyperactivity disorder was chosen
based on personal history of
experiencing its characteristic
symptoms, and a strong desire to
understand the nature of the disorder and its cultural/evolutionary significance.

Hypothesis:

Initial intent was to gather
academic support for an intuitive
sense of skepticism regarding the
status of the psychological
phenomenon being considered a
âdisorderâ in the first place, preferring instead to consider the symptoms to be a consequence of our inability as a species to adapt to such a rapidly changing world. The unprecedented rate of technological development has
presented us with a host of
bewildering distractions that no
society could ever be expected to
implement without accepting serious challenges due to our thoroughly specialized biological processing schemas. We have
created a culture of over-stimulation, and our natural response to it has generally been to become numb, scattered, and short-sighted. Attention deficit? Preposterous! With all this insanity we have to deal with, being constantly bombarded with
competing stimuli from every
direction, our attention has become
our most limited resource. It's no
disorder. It's the human condition.

Conclusion:

Actually... no. Not so fastâ¦ The
contents to follow will, if nothing else, demonstrate that it's not so simple.

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity
Disorder and the Development of
Executive Function

âThat kid just doesn't ever pay
attention. I wonder what is wrong
with himâ¦â . . . âHoney, better make
an appointment to see his doctor, it
must be some kind of chemical
imbalanceâ . . . âShouldn't he be
concerned about his grades? His
chores? Respecting his elders, his
teachers?â . . .

Weâre living in a culture of
diagnoses. An individual's unique
qualities are perceived as
shortcomings rather than recognized for what they could very well be - aspects of creative potential. In this investigation, I would like to propose that the very characteristics that cause one to be easily distracted, are the same traits that facilitate creative insight. So I have an idea - instead of
making ourselves perplexed by asking why, when we attempt to shove things down a child's throat we are not always received with rainbows of pleasure and gratitude - I suggest we ask a very different question: What does it mean to pay
attention?

I do not mean paying attention as in, âSit down and shut up!â, butâ¦
Attention. The heart of this entire present inquiry rests upon the
stunning realization of its full
implication. The things we choose to pay attention to - we choose for a very special reason. A reason that cuts to the core of our personality. A reason that we are defined by, shaped by our true sense of identity. The things that we give our attention - we give them the essence of our vitality. We allow
them to enter our beingâ¦ to penetrate usâ¦ and become us. Attentionâ¦ it is all that we are.

The Diagnostic and Statistical
Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth
Edition (DSM-5), published by the
American Psychiatric Association,
takes a decidedly different approach to this particular set of symptoms that have been collectively labeled a disorder. Specifically, it is categorized as:

âA neurodevelopmental disorder, which impairs the growthand development of the brain or central nervous systemâ. 1 This potentially affects the development of emotion, learning, self control, and memory throughout a person's early childhood through adulthood. Some examples of other
neurodevelopmental disorders are
intellectual disability (previously/less politely known as mental retardation), autism and autism spectrum disorders (e.g. Aspergers), Down syndrome, and
schizophrenia. 1

A combination of genetic and
environmental contributing factors
may be present including prenatal or infantile exposure to tobacco, alcohol, drugs or environmental toxins, premature birth, low birth weight, and of course, genetics - according to twin studies, about 75% of cases come from cognitive traits inherited from one of the parents. 2

What are these cognitive traits? A 2005 meta-analysis confirmed that
ADHD positively correlates with
impaired executive function - most
strongly and consistently with the
faculties of response inhibition,
working memory, vigilance, and
planning. 3

The first two - response
inhibition (or inhibitory control) and
working memory, are among the first mental systems to appear in an infant's developing brain, typically between 7 to 12 months. Then from age 3 to 5 they undergo a spurt of rapid development, along with the first stages of cognitive flexibility, goal-directed behavior, and capability of planning. During pre-adolescence there is a marked increase in verbal working memory, goal-directed behavior, response inhibition, selective attention, strategic planning and organizational skills. 4

Any attempt to link ADHD to a
specific physiological site is obviously futile, with all these cognitive functions developing independently at their own rate, and are progressively integrated together to form the complex network of brain systems
responsible for our ability to
concentrate.

When the development of some
combination of these systems is
compromised in an individual, effects manifest that characterize ADHD. They primarily include inattention and hyperactivity/impulsivity. In addition, resulting secondary effects may also have an impact on friends, family and colleagues due to disruptive behavior, academic issues, and relationship problems. Primarily
inattentive patients may be easily
distracted, forget details, or switch
excessively between tasks - unable to complete an activity without quickly getting bored. They may lose things, fail to listen, daydream, get confused, be physically or mentally sluggish or unable to follow directions. Those suffering from hyperactive/impulsive symptoms may experience fidgeting, squirming, restlessness, impatience, make inappropriate comments, uncontrolled emotion, and frequent interruptions. 5

To understand how these effects
manifest from poorly developed
executive function, it is vital that we
explore the nature of concentration in all of its intricacy. In order to
selectively focus on a particular
stimulus, other information from the senses must be filtered out and
ignored. Working memory is of
limited capacity, and allocating it
accordingly is part of our executive
function, the supervising attentional system.

Our dominant learned behavioral response to a stimulus, or âprepotent responseâ, was developed primarily to serve only our immediate survival needs. It must be overridden in order to achieve a more adaptive, delayed goal. We have just barely begun to learn, and the crucial skill that must be learned next is how to identify the signal from the noise to be filtered out. Paying attention is hard work - we are engaged in a battle with our own nature, by its very definition.

According to the executive function
theory that the study supports, this
filtering process called inhibitory
response is the first solid mental
process connected to concentration. 6 Working memory is the second cognitive development confirmed in the meta-analysis. It is a short-term,
limited-capacity cognitive buffer that stores information and permits its manipulation to guide decision
making and behavior. This is the place where the active, conscious agent of our awareness lives - the "I" with which we identify- it is here that the impressions of our experience that constitute our sense of self is accessed and processed. The prefrontal cortex
exerts âtop-downâ cognitive control, receiving its input from other cortical regions such as the association cortex, thalamus, and subcortical structures subserving emotion and motivation such as the amygdala and central striatum, or nucleus accumbens. 6

The negative effects of ADHD present conditions in which prepotent responses dominate behavior. ADHD as we are conceptualizing it here is a disorder of executive faculty, a reduced ability to exert and maintain cognitive control of behavior. It is a
diminished ability to inhibit responses to irrelevant stimuli (impaired interference suppression).

The third aspect of executive function is planning (forethought) -
thinking about and organizing the
activities required to achieve a desired goal. An anticipatory decision-making process to deal with the complexities of evaluating each set of interrelated decisions. It is a selection of missions and objectives for translating knowledge into action. 6

Finally, vigilance is sustained
concentration, the ability to maintain focus over prolonged periods of time. The deterioration in the ability to remain vigilant for critical signals with time, as indicated by a decline in the rate of the correct detection of signals is known as the vigilance decrement. This decrease in attention becomes significant within the first 15 minutes under most conditions, and even faster if there exists a high cognitive demand. 7

According to signal detection theory, we are engaged in a decision making process in which we continually vary our sensitivity to sensory input to allow more or less correct detections at the respective cost of false alarms. This is known as criterion shift. The strategy creates a bias, based on how many false alarms we are willing to tolerate to achieve a higher rate of detection, thereby
minimizing the consequences of either missed targets or false positives.

Vigilance is dependant on the state of arousal, taking place in the amygdala, which plays an important role in the recognition of emotional stimuli. 8

Research conducted in the 1940s
demonstrated that psychostimulant medications, when given to participants, caused a highly significant reduction of the
vigilance decrement. This is the targeted effect of modern pharmaceutical treatment for ADHD. 9

Medications however, only address the symptoms in the short-term. The best methods for long-term
management of ADHD involve
encouraging healthy learning skills
though behavioral therapy. Aerobic
exercise is proven to have a positive strengthening effect on the cognitive processes needing development. 10

The results of our research have
been enlightening. Our original
hypothesis, that ADHD is not actually a disorder, may be trivially plausible, as there is a long history of controversy regarding the diagnosis. There are certainly cases where it is misidentified due to other factors. However, quite early on in the course of study this stance was showing to be off-base, due to the very specified diagnostic criteria. After all, it is not by low intelligence or an act of rebellion that these actions occur. The
individual presenting actual ADHD
possesses both the desire and the
intellect to perform tasks, but is
specifically and excessively lacking in the areas of executive function,
compared to individuals of similar
age.

Clinical psychology is often perceived as arbitrarily judgemental. But when properly understood through the scope of its own definitional landscape, this misconception is quickly put to rest.

external_context.name: Ambient Narcissism

data.post:
Since I'm sometimes told that I should write a book about my crazy life (and also determined to not be the guy who's always full of ideas but never follows through), I started to actually do it. But there was still the problem of marketing, as in 'who is my target audience, and why would they want to buy my book'? It's not like I'm famous or something... so I needed to come up with an angle. It can be predominantly autobiographical content, but what is the book going to offer to someone who doesn't know or care about me whatsoever?

So I decided to make the book about the psycho-sociological effect of modern technology like smartphones and social networking. I'm calling it "Ambient Narcissism".

It builds upon the concept of ambient awareness, "a term used by social scientists to describe a new form of peripheral social awareness" (see Wikipedia link below), but also explores how the new paradigm brought about by social media affects the way we perceive and choose to display ourselves.

This past year I decided to change careers and have been learning software/web development full time. I am now trying to get some projects under my belt to build a portfolio and this could be a great opportunity for any local entrepreneurs who could benefit from a dynamic, database-backed website or a mobile app but without the budget to hire a professional developer. If this sounds maybe a little like you, consider giving me a try. Thanks!

media.description:
This isn't completely a joke, especially for me (and others with under 10 fingers).

There has been a kind of pissing match in programming and that is how seldom you need to use the mouse. The idea is if you memorize all the keyboard shortcuts you will be able to get more done.

My workflow philosophy is the opposite, aiming to use the keyboard as little as possible. This involves maintaining a comprehensive document from which to copy and paste.

This seems to follow the current trend in coding, to prefer the DRY principle over the WET principle:
DRY = Don't Repeat Yourself;
WET = Write Everything Twice (or We Enjoy Typing)!

Demand for programmers is growing way faster than the number of computer science students.

So what's the story, you ask, the inspiration behind my new business venture, the Internet of Non-Things? It may sound funny but it is not just a joke. It is actually very serious and meaningful... Allow me to explain:

The inspiration began during the Summer of 2016. I didn't have any Things, not even a cellphone. I had one but it got stolen.

Sometimes Things get stolen.

I lived a life without Things. Every day I would go to the library to use their Things to do my research, writing, and communication. Finally I took out a student loan and got a $20 Android phone. It was great... I had acquired a Thing.

I started teaching, and thought that a Thing with a bigger screen would be really nice for my classes. So I bought a cheap 10" tablet. It was great... I now had another Thing.

A few days later, I broke my Thing. I don't know how it happened, but there was a huge crack in the touchscreen and it wouldn't respond at all, you couldn't even get past the lock screen on my Thing.

Sometimes Things break.

So I spent a little more money and got a Windows Thing. That broke too. Eventually I would take it back to Walmart and get a new Windows Thing, but in the mean time I decided to finally break down and get an Apple Thing. After having a couple cheap tablets break on me, I figured a real iPad would help me actually get my work done. They control every aspect of their Things, so I thought I might have a dependable Thing for once.

The reliability of that Thing turned out to come with a heavy cost - tons of things I'm used to doing with my Things either weren't possible, or whatever hoops needing to be jumped through were beyond my level of patience to discover. Ugh... I had this really nice Thing that was crippled with crazy limitations. I just want to save a file. Wait... how do you save a file? 

I'd had quite enough of this wrestling with my Things. I was sick of it. I decided that the only solution was to do what normal students do, and buy a real laptop Thing. So I got a really nice Lenovo Thing.

Wow! Everything just worked! At last, I could just get things done on my Thing! It was amazing! It was surreal! It was.... too good for me. I thought for what I do I didn't really need such an expensive Thing. I figured that if I returned my expensive Thing, the money would go further buying other Things. I got a Raspberry Pi Thing, a tiny $35 Linux Thing. And I got an e-reader Thing, an easier on the eyes extended battery life Thing.

Wow! So very many Things! The great part of having several Things is then I could run apps for Android Things, iOS Things, Windows Things, and Linux Things! When the limitations of one Thing would bog me down, chances are it might work on another Thing. It turned out to facilitate a smoother workflow as well having multiple screens on different Things, instead of having to constantly switch tasks on one Thing.

The problem with having so many Things is carrying them around. I'd schlep my Things to a library or coffee shop, and it would take me 15 minutes to set up all my Things. Then what if I need to use the bathroom? One day I left my Things set up for a brief moment, only to return to catch campus police throwing all my Things into a trash bag. They were "keeping it safe", they said.

Constant harassments like these with campus police eventually led to me to have to quit school and leave Austin.

The cumbersome nature of too many things became extremely apparent when I hit the road. I found myself crippled by my Things. In Albuquerque I found myself a shopping cart with which to push around my Things, most treasured of all was my beautiful harmonium that I hand painted. I painted and bedazzled all my Things.

Yes...I was that guy pushing a shopping cart around town. But never had a bum cart been filled with such nice Things. Then one night.... One awful, terribly painful night...

While at McDonald's in Albuquerque, my beloved harmonium disappeared. Someone had obviously stolen it. 

Ouch. At first my incredible loss did not even register. It actually took a couple days for the devastation to set in. That instrument had come to define me. It was not only my livelihood, my source of income, it was how I expressed myself. Without an instrument...I was lost. I no longer had my most precious Thing.

From that point onward, I would turn my creative energy to my other Things. My electronic Things. I would adapt my ability to make music to not require an acoustic Thing. At the same time I was getting heavily involved with coding, learning to program my Things. I discovered that writing programs can be just as powerful of an outlet for creativity as music, if not more so! Coding is problem solving - which I have found to represent the highest level of human ingenuity. Once I began to understand this, I was hooked. I was having so much fun nerding out with my Things, I rarely missed my old Thing - which I could only blame myself for losing - it was too much for me. Too many Things.

Our travels took us from New Mexico to Arizona to Cali. San Francisco turned out to be another tragedy for our Things...

They robbed us while we were sleeping. They stole nearly all our Things. The bass guitar Thing, 3 computing Things...

All we are left with now is the little Android Thing, and my iPad Thing. A very very sad day for Things. But once the initial anger subsided... I ironically found myself extremely relieved. All of a sudden I could walk around freely, unencumbered by so many Things!

And as far as my productivity... I'm actually enjoying the challenge of just working with one Thing (even though it ended up being the Apple Thing...). In reality, humans are terrible multitaskers. It seems that possibly having multiple Things encourages switching tasks haphazardly... With only one Thing, it forces you to stick to one task longer since you can't so quickly glance over to another Thing. It manages your attention differently, and often quite positively.

And here is where it gets interesting... and responsible for inspiring...

The Internet of Non-Things.

I'm finding that the sudden forced shift in my workflow precipitated by this radical reduction in my arsenal of Things has modified the trajectory of my programming. With only an iPad Thing, I can only really code from within a text editor or web browser. I can no longer use a Python interpreter or a Java compiler - those only ran on my other Things.

I must now develop in the cloud exclusively. I must turn my focus to JavaScript, which will run on any Thing that has a web browser. I had not appreciated this before when I had all my Things. 

I have learned that we are in many ways slaves to our Things. This experience convinces me that overall happiness tends to have an inverse relationship to our level of ownership of Things. Now I know what I must do - to push our community towards independence from Things. 

Welcome to the Internet of Non-Things.

Traveling in the winter with peripheral vascular disease is an interesting bag. If I get too cold my blood vessels close up which presents a threat to my medical safety.

But I still had a seven hour walk, and hadn't been able to get my meds. So I went to the ER in Fremont... got a Procardia and a Norco and they sent me on my way. But wait... my discharge instructions say to be very careful to stay warm.

What's a wingnut to do??? I went back in and made them get me a cab. How did I do that?

By sitting down, silly! 
I do what I want.

title: Bobby Towers was at Google Visitor's Center.

data.post:
The Wingnut's Guide to California

So as soon as I hit the highway out of San Francisco I was in handcuffs. "I don't know you, and I don't know what you're capable of", he said.

Now, as some of you know I have a messed up hand. And since he was using excessive force, I was understandably pissed. So I made them take me to the hospital out of spite. I said that the officer attacked me and cut off the circulation in my limb which suffers from peripheral vascular disease, and had precipitated an iscemic occlusion. They prescribed me blood pressure medication.

I was gonna walk 40 miles to Silicon Valley, about 16 hours. But I got to Oakland (most ghetto-ass place ever) and my feet started to hurt, so I went to the train station and told the girl I needed to get my blood pressure medication for my vascular condition.

It didn't work. "If you want to go there you need money", she said. So what does a wingnut do in this situation? Listen carefully....

You sit down. Just sit down right there.

I fished out my prescription and discharge paperwork, and checked the time. Five minutes later, she called me over and handed me my ticket.

Does this make me a dirtbag? How does that stupid expression go.... sorry, not sorry. I just don't care. I do what I want. Whatever, fuck you.

Oops... I just realized that I had set my posts to private because I was writing some pretty stupid notes to myself on here, and forgot to switch back the setting. So my last few updates weren't published...

I decided to go to San Francisco, partly because they have one of the best public transit systems in the country, and I've been doing pretty well with my recent coding work. 

During my psychology studies in Austin I found myself procrastinating heavily, and in doing so rediscovered my love for computer programming. Python rocks... It's the best "beginner" language to come out since Basic, and for the past few weeks I've been totally immersed in it. 

I want to talk to anyone on here who is interested in programming, and would encourage others to get into it. We're all on computers after all... We ought to learn to use them!

Got abducted and taken to a hippie concert. I am so bored... This music is so lame it's actually painful to listen to, yet everyone is dancing and blissed out and totally into it. It seems like there must be something wrong with me that I'm not able to enjoy this...shit, my incredibly gracious host/abducter paid for my ticket so I could go in to the show, but I'm admittedly unappreciative, even a bit spiteful because I was having more fun outside where it's not crowded with people and don't have to be subjected to this.

media.description: Hot off the press! You can find my article on LSD in the new issue of @[151251584937444:274:The Challenger Street Newspaper]!

data.post: Hot off the press! You can find my article on LSD in the new issue of The Challenger Street Newspaper!

"You're writing a book? What are you, 30 years old? What have you done in your life that's so fucking interesting that anyone would want to read about it in a book?

I told the drunk dude that I was glad he was asking me that, since it's exactly the question I need to be asking to develop an angle. Why *would* anyone want to read my book?

Then when I thought about it more, I realized what the *real* question should have been: 

What is so fucking interesting about *anything* that makes it worth reading?

Reading is kind of a chore, and today there are more words shoved in our faces than ever battling for our precious deficient attention. In fact most people have already stopped reading this post, if they even started at all.

I find that a lot of the time it's not so much what is being said but *how* it is said, presenting the material in a novel, accessible, inspiring form. My favorite authors and speakers could talk about fucking sports and keep my interest. I've listened to Penn Jillette talk for countless hours about his diet that helped him lose 100 pounds, and it nearly makes me want to start eating nothing but whole plants with no salt sugar or oil, and wash it down with a blueberry cacao cayenne smoothie. And I barely weigh 140 pounds.

And I hate blueberries.

data.text: Mid-terms are done, not all scores in yet but never mind that... it's enough of a miracle that I even got them done. But I still can't stop freaking out... I feel like I'm in a crazy video game where I'm being shot through hoses and shit, having to make all the right turns with lightning-fast reaction time.

data.post: Can't say I'm gonna miss that feeling. It's as if I just woke up from a 6-month nightmare, all the while telling myself it was worth it because "it's my education".

This track of mine just started getting like a hundred times more monthly streams than usual! I don't know how these things work in internet land but whoever is listening to and sharing it, thank you! It actually made me like.... almost 5 dollars! This song has a very special history:

It came from a song I wrote with my dad in like 1998. I played bass and he played guitar. We set up a fostex 4-track and jammed it out, then I programmed the drums, wrote the lyrics and sang it. This was to present a demo to pitch the song to the band, but when the singers heard it they said that I should just sing it myself! So this track marks the time that I emerged as an actual vocalist.

A dubstep track typically follows the form of 32 bars building up to the drop. But this one just has a 2 bar windup and smacks you right in the face. The combination of modern electronic sounds and melodic vocals and more traditional songwriting is what I imagine has caused this track to be the most popular on the album.

I love the line, "Before you go, stop and take a look around". That's why I decided to end the song with it repeating on the fadeout. It reminds us to be more present during pivotal moments in our lives. No matter what choices we make, we should always have a time where we reflect, breathe, and take a look around at the situation you are leaving. Then whatever the outcome, at least you will know that you took that moment before making a crucial decision. And who knows... It may just cause you to make a better one.

I'm writing a book, using my past 10 years of Facebook posts as an outline. So far I've compiled all my status updates and am using them to form a narrative. I currently have around 150 pages of material, and through this process I've noticed something very interesting:

2013 was a major creative explosion for me. It was the year that I finally recorded and released my debut album which represented over 15 years of musical composition - my life's work. I also posted more on Facebook than ever: over 11,000 words. After that, I went back to my usual 2-3000.

Until this year. My word count for 2016 is pushing 15,000 and there's still 2 months left!

That's such a huge difference that demands an explanation! The only thing I can think of is that those are the years during which I moved to a new place and started school. However in 2011 I went to Israel to study, undoubtedly the biggest move of my life, and wrote relatively little. On Facebook, at least. I do recall an enormous amount of private email activity at the time. So yes definitely... Traveling and school are both possible factors.

I encourage anyone who takes social media seriously to go to your Facebook settings and download your data. You get files containing the entirety of your profile activity. Yes, everything! If you publicly share your Pandora, Spotify, etc., then you get to wade through EVERY SONG you've listened to, so it's a bit overwhelming. But it's worth it. To help understand yourself. What personal revelations will you discover?

Teaser post:

Some BIG life changes in the works! Will not be going to school anymore after Fall term, to make room for exciting new projects. Not gonna go into detail yet... but it MAY involve traveling.

School is a great thing... If you don't know what you're doing.

David Murney  Jim Tifft Paul Damphair I got my Plato's Cave paper back that I did for Philosophy class. The only marks on it were "excellent idea, negativity bias", which means I can only assume I got full credit. Or an "A", for those who prefer alphabetic achievement ratings. If you twist my cyberontological arm, I'll post a link for any and all to read.

This week we began the study of Descartes and had a class debate over whether interaction with other individuals is necessary to know that we exist. Since I was practically going into seizures in my chair I had to be the asshole who asks "what does it mean to exist"?

That got the class's attention. I continued: "If I imagine a triangle, does it exist? By some definition, yes! It has a physical existence as a pattern of neurons in my brain!"

What would these poor students do without me? It's fucking philosophy, if you don't leave the room feeling like you're tripping on acid, you're doing it wrong.

It's quite unlike me to leave you all hanging for such a long time, and it pains me greatly to consider the anxiety I have undoubtedly caused by my failure to keep you constantly updated as usual. The past few weeks have been so uniquely stimulating that scarcely did a brief moment occur that I found myself thinking of Facebook. I apologize deeply as it was not my intention to ignore you, however I have some heartbreaking news for those of you awaiting my return for which I've been struggling to find the proper words: I have decided I am quitting school and will not be returning home as planned.

When I read the article I thought it must be a joke, for it seemed too fantastical, too perfect to be a real place. The website seemed legit though, so I proceeded to make some phone calls before embarking on the trip. I figured it wouldn't set me back excessively to spend a day there to check it out. Little did I know that they were looking for a full-time music teacher, and when I told them my story they decided to give me an interview on the spot. They said that although I lack credentials, the formal education typically required to teach music, my extensive experience with people of all walks of life and unique approach more than make up for it, and that I would be a great addition to their organization.

They call it the Ukuleground, but it's not just for kids. It's not just about ukuleles either. They offer lessons in guitar, piano, violin and voice, but their program happens to involve itself the most with the instrument that has established itself as a conveniently practical, surprisingly versatile, universally accessible icon of modern music: The ukulele. It is used for a multitude of styles, everything from classical to punk rock. It requires very little hand strength and the chords are less complicated than guitar. It sits particularly well with the vocal range and is so small and lightweight you can practically wear it. I was originally inspired to pick up the ukulele by performers such as Tiny Tim and Amanda Palmer, and I found it so addictive, so intimately expressive that I felt like everyone should have one. It has such a pure musical simplicity that makes it the perfect personal accessory to carry around. Now that I am part of the Ukuleground, I can do my part to get them into the hands of more people.

The service that we provide here is a charity for the community. It has full nonprofit status and falls under the category of music and art therapy, funded partly by donations but primarily by selling the instruments that are manufactured and uniquely decorated in-house by the clients and staff. One of the rooms is a workshop where you can learn how to build your very own ukulele, and then we have the finishing room where they are brought to life as unique art pieces with all kinds of oils, paints and stains. Some people choose to then add  sparkles, glitter and rhinestones, and spray on a coat of varnish for a bedazzled uke. I wish you could see the joy on their faces when these folks discover that they can create a real instrument with their own hands.

The Ukuleground was inspired by the work of Neuroscientist Daniel Levitin, author of "This Is Your Brain On Music". In his book, he challenges the notion that music is merely "auditory cheesecake", an evolutionary byproduct of human communication faculties, and presents his case that it has continually served an essential role in our psychosocial development throughout our history as a species. It is an entirely recent phenomenon, he says, that some people do not consider themselves musicians. Perpetuated by the myth that talent is something that you either have or you don't, music has been taken out of the hands of the common people and become the domain of an elite few. Curiously however, music is the only skill for which we have come to demand such a high level of proficiency in order to enjoy doing. Levitin uses sports and cooking as counterexamples. You don't have to be as skilled as Michael Jordan to play a game of basketball out back, or as skilled as Rachel Ray in the kitchen to make a nice dinner. We have come to treat music differently, creating the perception that unless you can achieve a certain level of technical mastery, you aren't good enough to take part in the activity. Its wonderful power as a medium for creative personal expression and communal bonding has begun to fade from our culture. It is this unfortunate situation that our facility aims to reverse, and provides the cornerstone of our philosophy: To empower individuals to explore their creative potential. At the Ukuleground, we believe that music is not merely something that we do. It is what we are. Music for the people, by the people and of the people.

Besides empowering people by enabling them to create their very own instruments with which to make music, the Ukuleground is also empowering some to become teachers, such as myself. I never thought I could have such a positive effect on so many people. So although it is with deep sorrow that I will not be returning to Austin, I hope you at least now understand why I feel I have been called to do this. 

I love you all so much and you will be sorely missed. But perhaps one day, the stars will align and the city that is known as the "live music capital of the world" may achieve another level of greatness and create a similar music space of its own. I can only dream. Until then my beloved Facebook friends, I bid you farewell. I have some very special work to do.

media.title: Mobile Uploads
media.description:
Unexpected benefit of scanning and throwing away all my school papers: I can convert handouts to text and edit them, particularly useful for assignment guidelines and study guides.

Nothing is without headaches though. I got frustrated with the scanner and had to ask the tech for help. I shared with him the reasons for my newfound extreme hatred of paper, as well as my anticipation of my professors' butthurt over my decision to go on strike from it.

(Some people don't like the term "butthurt", but it is the only word that accurately describes the situation when a teacher is so insecure as to feel offended if a student glances at a device during their class, as if the issue of people failing to pay attention is a recent epidemic beginning with the invention of the smartphone...)

"If your teacher has a problem with you using a tablet in class, they need to get over it!", he said.

"You don't understand...", I lamented. "It's like hot sauce in their buttholes."
