"A person's preferred music enhances connections between different regions of the brain, a pattern called the default mode network (DMN), the researchers report. This network is associated with introspection, self-awareness, mind-wandering and possibly imagination. 

When the DMN is activated, another network, the task-positive network (TPN)âwhich is involved in goal-oriented activityâis shut down. The two states can be thought of as focus on the outside world (the TPN) and focus on inner thoughts (the DMN)."

data.post: My grandma is the best pianist I've ever heard (not in technical ability but in musical expressiveness) and she picks the most interesting stuff. Nothing ruins a keyboard piece worse than a player who bangs it out too fast without letting it breathe. Except for the Prokofiev Toccata, which should be played as fast as humanly possible. Her Chopin is especially good... But out of everything I heard her play over the years, it was the Scarlatti that grabbed me the most, and I would ask her repeatedly to play it throughout my whole life... sometimes years would go by and she would forget it but I begged her to learn it again. And she was captivated by it each time... It has the elegance of baroque music (which is when it was written) but the harmonic complexity of later classical, it was totally ahead of its time. "This is PURE MUSIC", she would say. This is all I want to hear right now - luckily if I listen to 5 volumes a day, it will last a for a whole week. This playlist contains all 555 harpsichord sonatas, but the user put the 34 disks in reverse order. Play them backwards, last video first and you'll hear them in the chronological order in which they were written. Oh and the harpsichord is perfect because there's no silly dynamics, you get each note in your face full strength!

Then they inspected her anus. They found nothing. Then they performed a CAT scan. They found nothing.

All this, because one drug-sniffing dog indicated to federal agents she might be carrying drugs.

The ACLU says the feds did all this without a search warrant.

And all this without her consent."

data.post:
"A professor stood before his philosophy class and had some items in front of him. When the class began, he wordlessly picked up a very large and empty mayonnaise jar and proceeded to fill it with golf balls. He then asked the students if the jar was full. They agreed that it was.The professor then picked up a box of pebbles and poured them into the jar. He shook the jar lightly. The pebbles rolled into the open areas between the golf balls. He then asked the students again if the jar was full. They agreed it was.
The professor next picked up a box of sand and poured it into the jar. Of course, the sand filled up everything else. He asked once more if the jar was full.. The students responded with a unanimous âyes.âThe professor then produced two Beers from under the table and poured the entire contents into the jar effectively filling the empty space between the sand.The students laughed..âNow,â said the professor as the laughter subsided, âI want you to recognize that this jar represents your life. The golf balls are the important thingsâ-your family, your children, your health, your friends and your favorite passionsâ-and if everything else was lost and only they remained, your life would still be full. The pebbles are the other things that matter like your job, your house and your car.. The sand is everything elseâ-the small stuff.âIf you put the sand into the jar first,â he continued, âthere is no room for the pebbles or the golf balls. The same goes for life.If you spend all your time and energy on the small stuff you will never have room for the things that are important to you.Pay attention to the things that are critical to your happiness.Spend time with your children. Spend time with your parents. Visit with grandparents. Take your spouse out to dinner. Play another 18. There will always be time to clean the house and mow the lawn.Take care of the golf balls firstâ-the things that really matter. Set your priorities. The rest is just sand.One of the students raised her hand and inquired what the Beer represented. The professor smiled and said, âIâm glad you asked.â The Beer just shows you that no matter how full your life may seem, thereâs always room for a couple of Beers with a friend."

data.post: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iz5bCtvhNcU When I first made this song in 2002, I flooded my hometown with it by burning about 200 copies and just giving them away to everyone I saw. That's what I had to do before social media if I wanted people to hear something. It got a great response - it was quite an amazing thing to be hanging around downtown and hear a car drive by blasting my song, pull over next to me and roll the window down while singing along! It was actually one of my first attempts at electronic music, and now here's a brand-new version a decade later.
https://soundcloud.com/bobtowers/december-wub

media.description: "Hello?" . . . A couple of girls were talking about me as I was goofing around on my tablet at the bar. "Oh my god, look at the size of that guy's fucking phone". "Yo, I don't think that's a fucking phone, it's like a mini fucking ipad, it's too big to be a fucking phone. Watch, I'll go ask him". She walked over to my tableâ¦ "Hey, is that a mini fucking ipad, or a fucking phone"? I explained that it was a Nexus fucking tablet. "Cool, 'cause my friend thought it was a fucking phone, but I knew it was way too big to be a fucking phone". That's when I put it up to my ear and pretended to fucking answer it.

data.post:
Nearly done w my 1st term of college, just 1 final 2 go & it's playing Auld Lang Syne on the piano & a written exam, piece of cake, easy A. What's more important than grades though is what I've learned:

1. I really, REALLY suck at math. Complete waste of time, just bland logic w no substance.
2. I'm AWESOME at philosophy, but it's also a waste of time.
3. I'm a damn good writer. But I also learned that no good writer thinks they are, so I must not be.
4. Music for me is second-nature. I ought to do it all the time.

Studying classical guitar next term. Gonna go pick out my new instrument... expect to see pictures! (Oh, and vids 4 sure!) <3

I have learned all of these the hard way, by trial and error and 15 years of sifting through and getting more confused by nearly every teacher and resource I find... and now I want to help YOU get on track right, while paying only what you can afford. Call or message for info!

Wandering Goat Songwriter's Night was awesome! I stopped right in the middle of my opening song to tell a goofy story about one time when I played that song. Successfully joked about heroin... not an easy feat. Then I finished with a song that, as I explained to the audience, was so stupid that I'd actually never played it before. It was the best one, because it was so stupid.

Having unilateral hearing, it is as if I perceive music as a two dimensional blueprint of a three dimensional sonic architecture. This forces my mind into an active interpretation mode in order to reconstruct the song.

"To understand and discern the end of a concept from its beginning, derive one from another and compare them to each other. To judge with the Torah's principles of derivation until it is known what the essence is and how to learn what is proper and what is not according to tradition. This topic is called Talmud." - Mishne Torah, Hilkoth Talmudh Torah Chapter 1

data.post:
Cat dreams

The first nightmare I remember having as a child(toddler?) was a recurring nightmare.  I had it at least three times throughout my childhood, and it involves a cat.  Or did it... check it out:

I was playing outside in my front yard in my hometown of Seneca Falls, NY.  Immediately once the conscious part of the dream begins, I look up towards the road at a terrible sight... my kitty cat... getting run over by a car. (Oh no!!!)

I know it didn't get hit by the tire.  It went perfectly straight over.  As I run up towards the street to see if the cat was dead or not, I start to notice something quite strange...

It wasn't my cat.  It wasn't a cat at all.  Or, it WAS a cat, my kitty cat, but something about its existence was seriously changed during the time the car passed over it.  It was not a dead cat... nor was it alive.

"It turned into a pile of cookies," my mom said.

And as I walk up to take a closer look, in fact, it was true.

Lying in the middle of the road, was nothing but a pile of chocolate chip cookies where the cat (or what we thought was the cat) was.

Then... out of nowhere...(remember, this IS a nightmare)...

A big ugly clown head, filling my entire field of vision, screams at me!  I wake up, screaming as well, sweaty...



All through my childhood I have had other recurring dreams involving dead cats.  Cats falling out of 2-story windows... Dead cats lying in boxes...

Do you think this means anything?

Raphael

All right, how's this?

Just had to change my hat.  I was originally signed up with Aish HaTorah, and then my Rabbi recommended this one...  Jewish Renewal is the movement I'm currently involved with, so I guess I'll fit right in!!  We're the ones whos shabbat services sound more like rock concerts and we can davven shachrit in 50 words or less!  Shrimp and Pork may only be eaten in chinese restaurants, and our high holidays... wait, I'd better not get myself in trouble already...

I grew up near Ithaca, NY.....then I moved to the west coast 2 years ago to start over.  And now....I'm actually going on this trip as another spy, to see if the grapes and pomegranates are really as huge as our ancestors say.  I will most likely be traveling with you all one way, and when our tour is all over, that's when I'll start my real adventure in the land.  No way, if I'm flying all the way to Israel, am I coming back here after a week and a half...
Check out some of my original jewish music here: http://www.myspace.com/raphaelyaakov
See you all soon!
